node.title: With a federal election looming, the Great Resignation presents politicians with big opportunities
node.alt: Labor politicians sit with large gaps between them in the green House of Representatives
node.description: For employers trying to keep and attract the best staff, COVID-inspired upheaval in Australia's job market presents enormous challenges. For politicians facing a looming election, it presents opportunities, writes David Speers.
node.content:
["It's too early to know whether Australia will experience a similar upheaval to the \"Great Resignation\" underway in the United States.\u00a0", "Anecdotally, employers are spotting similar trends to the American phenomenon. The smart ones are readying themselves, finding ways to make their workplace more attractive. The rest are either oblivious or assuming this seismic rebalancing of the employer-employee relationship is just a passing fad.", "It was around 12 months after the pandemic really hit in the US that something started to change. In March this year, the so-called \"quit rate\" began to climb. This rate measures the number of workers voluntarily leaving a job, and by April it had hit a record high.", "", "
For many employees, working from home during the pandemic has been an eye-opener.(Pexels: Anna Shvets)
", "In August a new record was set, followed by another in September, with 4.4 American million workers leaving their jobs in just one month.\u00a0", "There are a range of reasons behind the mass movement and exodus. For some, working from home has been an eye-opener. They want more flexibility and freedom. They're re-assessing the priority of work in their lives.\u00a0", "Others have found the work from home experience utterly exhausting, as have those serving at the frontline of COVID in the healthcare sector. They've had enough. Then there are those sick of being underpaid and overworked who are now chasing a better deal.\u00a0", "
It's not just about more money
", "Dr Anthony Klotz from Texas A&M University, who coined the term \"Great Resignation\", says there are four trends: a backlog of resignations from those who hung onto positions they would have otherwise left during COVID, heightened levels of burnout, \"pandemic epiphanies\" leading to lifestyle change, and finally those who simply do not want to return to the office environment.\u00a0", "The unemployment rate has fallen in the US, but the participation rate remains well below its pre-COVID levels. No one can be certain whether this will be a temporary blip or a permanent exodus. In the meantime, employers are scrambling to hold onto good staff and find ways to attract new workers to fill their vacancies.\u00a0", "It's not just about offering more money, although that's part of it. US wages grew by 1.5 per cent in the three months to the end of September, the biggest jump in 20 years.\u00a0", "It's also about offering employees greater flexibility (including the ability to work fewer hours and work from home), work they can value in their lives and a sense of purpose. The power imbalance between the boss and the worker may still exist, but the dial is shifting some.\u00a0", "It's hard to believe these trends and preconditions don't exist in Australia. Indeed, \"job hopping\" is already on the rise. The Nine Newspapers this week reported a big jump in the number of people shifting employment compared to pre-COVID, based on data from LinkedIn.\u00a0", "", "
Many American workers have been burnt out serving at the frontline of COVID in the healthcare sector.(ABC News: Brendan Esposito)
", "
Challenges for employers, questions for politicians\u00a0
", "Australian workers are at least looking for change, if not an exit from the jobs market. Some analysts predict the full force will be felt in March, once Christmas bonuses are pocketed and workers weigh their prospects for the year ahead.\u00a0", "Mass movement within the Australian economy isn't necessarily a bad thing. It can spur long-overdue wages growth and even stronger productivity. Any mass exodus from the jobs market is a bigger problem.\u00a0", "For employers trying to keep and attract the best staff, all of this presents enormous challenges. For politicians facing a looming election, it presents opportunities.\u00a0", "", "
US employers are scrambling to hold onto good staff and find ways to attract new workers.(Unsplash:\u00a0Marten Bjork)
", "If Australians spend this summer contemplating a new direction in their lives and work, they'll be looking for politicians speaking their language. Those who understand the desire for workplace flexibility or career mobility, for a new work-life balance, or perhaps a shift to the regions.\u00a0", "Labor is hoping to tap into that sentiment with its promise of faster NBN speeds \u2014 a way to improve the WFH possibilities. There's scope for both sides to do far more.", "What rights should workers have to demand work-from-home arrangements? How can the exploitation of those who are over-worked at home be avoided? What does the future hold for our CBDs? What standard of health, education and infrastructure should we expect in the regions?\u00a0", "Having a conversation about the post-pandemic economy and workforce beyond simply predicting things will \"roar back\" would be a start.", "We'll get that conversation going tonight on Q&A.\u00a0", "David Speers is the host of Insiders, which airs on ABC TV at 9am on Sunday or on iView."]
